content_scrubbed:
The economic woes of millennials are due to structural changes in the economy, so blaming it on the BOOMERS is like shaking your fist at the sun for rising in the morning. 

However, I feel that some of the attitude on here is a bit.. schizophrenic. It seems like every week there is a post mocking people for discouraging students from pursuing the liberal_arts. Well, if you drift into college without a plan and end up on the five year track without much in the way of hard skills... you end up on reddit blaming boomers. 

Going into debt to obtain a generic BA cannot be justified. Sure, if you go to Harvard, or Princeton, you can go work in consulting or Wall Street with a BA in comparative literature (this is what Michael Lewis did). 

But attending an expensive private school that isn't Ivy League to study history? That is a monumental waste of four years and tens of thousands of dollars. Accounting, engineering, nursing, etc., vocational career tracks, are still a safe bet (but nothing is sure anymore). 

I work in construction -- and I just recently hired a guy, about my age, who has an MA in history from a very highly regarded school, to dispatch trucks and wash equipment. He[.] making more here ($19 an hour) than he did at his last job.
